node.text: Faced with the challenges of building on an island, a New York–based family embraces the benefits of prefab design with a custom Axiom timber home by @turkeldesign.

node.title: This Inviting Prefab Home in Martha’s Vineyard Takes Cues From Nature

node.text:
Dubbed the Zen Den, this serene home by Whitney Brown and Carlos Naude, the creative duo behind @workingholidaystudio, is brightened with an infusion of natural light and now serves as the couple’s personal residence and design showroom.
-
Check out @workingholidayspaces to see more of Whitney and Carlos’ work.

—

—
Renovation by @marmolradziner
#dwellescapes #dwellxgenesis #gv80 #lewhouse #richardneutra #midcentury #midcenturyicon

node.text:
Though smack dab in the middle of Los Angeles’ vibrant East Side, this home feels like a secret hideaway. Steps from a street lined with apartment buildings, modest older homes, and commercial warehouses, the single-level house, with just one window on the front facade, looks inward, becoming more open as you move through it to the surprisingly lush backyard. “We wanted to explore indoor/outdoor living in a different way,” says owner Mark Motonaga of @rioshome, who renovated the 1920s-era home with his partner, artist Guy Clouse. Read the complete feature on Atwater Hideaway, nominated in this year’s Dwell Design Awards, when you visit dwell.com/design-awards
–

node.title: An Architect’s Venice Home Draws Inspiration From Around the World

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Dwell on September 08, 2021. May be an image of kitchen.

node.text:
Despite its tiny footprint, Olive—an aptly named green houseboat—is fully equipped for a modern lifestyle. The 59-foot floating abode was designed in 2019 by its architect owners, and currently sits on Regents Canal in London. While extremely adorable, the home’s design is equally practical. It’s “a contemporary and timeless vessel in harmony with her fluvial surroundings,” notes @aucoot. They’re not wrong: past the sofa and two-seater dining table is a relatively large kitchen with oak-faced cabinets, along with a counter-to-ceiling backsplash that adds a sense of openness to the space. The opposite side of the boat holds the bedroom, along with a bathroom complete with an eco-friendly composting toilet. There’s even a charming outdoor seating area on the bow that extends a warm welcome through glass doors. Best of all, the houseboat is looking for new owners. Head to the link in bio to see more of the quaint home, currently listed for £125,000.
–
Photos Courtesy of @aucoot

node.text:
When the architects at ATOMAA first approached this crumbling home in the Italian Alps, it was in pretty rough shape. But its agrarian heritage and abundance of reusable materials were undeniable, guiding a contemporary renovation that honors the past. The 1,530-square-foot home—dubbed House Cinsc—carefully balances authenticity with modern intervention, making it one family’s perfect retreat amid the towering peaks of Varzo, Italy. With the help of local artisans, Milan-based @atomaa.eu restored the exterior using stones from the original structure. The rugged shell now houses an unadorned yet welcoming space from which to observe the surrounding landscape. Inside, an entirely wooden core traces the shape of the stone exterior and lends the home warmth within “a context strongly characterized by stone,” as the ATOMAA team describes it. Just as intended, the restored home is rigorous and minimal, yet comfortably rustic. Perhaps more importantly, its neighboring rock formations and idyllic pastures remain untouched. Take the full tour of House Cinsc at the link in bio.
–
Photos by @albertostrada
Story by Grace Bernard

node.text:
Our latest issue hits stands in one week! In anticipation, we’re revisiting this high-drama home that was featured on our September/October 2019 cover.
Cornerstone House, in Melbourne’s leafy suburb of Northcote, balances rough and refined surfaces to theatrical effect. Built with rough-cut stone and boasting a facade of black-plate aluminum ribbons, the home’s striking design stems from the palpable tension between architects Asha Nicholas and Chris Stanley of @splinter_society_architecture. “Asha is into order, refinement, and simplicity, while I’m into chaos and more,” explains Stanley. As it’s struck by light from new angles throughout the day, the home is given a dramatic sense of constant motion that makes it a true spectacle. See the whole performance when you try Dwell+ at the link in bio.
–

node.text:
Following a fire that destroyed its rear half, a home in Melbourne gets a serene addition that honors what stood before. "We wanted to preserve as much of the existing home as we could”, says Benjamin Shields, founder of architecture studio @dreamer.lab. The client, a nurse living in the Ascot Vale neighborhood, had requested a “nature-filled retreat capable of hosting large gatherings of extended family and friends, while still providing moments of restorative seclusion,” Shields remembers. As it was, the home was poorly insulated, didn’t connect to the backyard, and had dark interiors. The new rear addition—which features a kitchen and living and dining areas on the ground level, along with a primary bedroom on the first floor—now overlooks the backyard and a strategically placed courtyard, maintaining privacy from nearby neighbors. To preserve the heritage elements of the building, Shields left a section of the wall in the courtyard as a seat, and recycled the bricks for use in the paving, among other design considerations. A fully native green roof now leads off the primary bedroom to create a private terrace planted with a grassy flower garden. "[It’s] my favorite part of the project," says Shields. "It’s a very special place—it’s lush, quiet, and there’s a view over the native plants to the neighboring roofs. The client is also really starting to make the project her own through planting—we love it when we visit!” Take a walk through the home and its remarkable new addition at the link in bio.
–
Photos by @arorygardiner 
Story by @mandikeighran 
Landscaping for Green Roof @fytogreen_australia

node.text:
It is perhaps misleading to call these three structures a summer house. But measuring 890 square feet altogether, referring to them as a set of summer houses would imply something grander than a modest trio of cabins tucked into a defunct granite quarry. The cluster began as a single “little box” on the island of Vinalhaven, Maine, that owners Nick and Nadja van Praag purchased after patiently waiting for something to crop up. Over the years, they’d make interior renovations with local builder, caretaker, and lifelong island resident Matt Conway. Later, after purchasing the adjacent lot where a mobile home stood, they expanded with an entirely new plan: @go_logic architectural designer Riley Pratt borrowed the idea from @alvaraalto sketches depicting a “peeled apart” summer cabin, in which interconnected volumes surround a central courtyard. The resulting trio of autonomous bedroom cabins is constructed with cross-laminated timber panels, and finished by Conway’s crew with mitered white pine. In time they’ll turn hoary, matching both the granite landscape and the local cottage vernacular. “The most amazing thing is the way Riley sited the place,” Nick says. “By raising and angling the buildings, it embraces the landscape and the ocean in a way that I could not have imagined.” Try Dwell+ at the link in bio for more on how the van Praag’s brought a Finnish design concept to the island of Vinalhaven.
–
Photos by @carolltaveras

node.text:
After a renovation, this 1955 home in Portland now boasts fresh interiors and a covered patio for lounging in every season, rain or shine. The first thing that architect Risa Boyer of @risaboyerarchitecture noticed upon walking through the home pre-reno wasn’t the interiors. “What stood out to me the most, once you got through the maze of the entry, was the connection to the backyard,” she says. While Boyer appreciated the sliding glass doors and transom windows at the rear of the house, the architect knew the indoor/outdoor connection could be even stronger. As it was, a solid wall down the center of the living spaces segmented the backyard views and hindered circulation. The mix of finishes from different eras—including a cottage-style pink-and-blue kitchen—weren’t doing the classic midcentury any favors. With the help of contractor @hammerandhandbuilds, the team extended the roof to create a generous covered patio area, accessed by a 23-foot-long glass door that slides into the wall for a seamless indoor/outdoor flow. New skylights in the roofing of the covered patio only emphasize the feeling of being outdoors. Swipe to see some before photos and head to the link in bio for the full renovation when you try Dwell+.
–

node.text:
Our latest print issue drops on September 15th! In anticipation, we’re revisiting the awe-inspiring home that graced the cover of our September/October 2020 issue—and also claimed Runner-Up and Community Pick for best bathroom in the 2020 Dwell Design Awards.
Square House by New York City architecture studio @levenbetts is surely more sanctuary than ruin, but it walks a beautiful line between the two. For the owners, the guesthouse was about designing a vestige 500 years into the future and working backward to a functional home. Several years of dialogue—steered by that idea of design from the future—led to a quietly monolithic concrete box set in a contemplative landscape of rocks and moss. The connection to the outdoors is one of the home’s most astounding characteristics. Although it reads as a single story, the floor level rises and lowers with the site’s topography, intentionally altering your perspective as you progress through the house. “When you’re in the sunken living room, you’re lower than the ground plane and you see nature at a very different scale,” says Stella Betts, cofounder of Levenbetts. “It’s an idea of porosity, or being out in nature and then entering every room in the house from wherever.” Take the full tour of Square House when you try Dwell+ at the link in bio.
–
Photos by @edeani
Story by Sheila Kim
Structural Engineering by @silman.structural
Landscape Design by @markpeterkeane

node.text:
This home is so energy efficient that the family living in it, a young couple and their two children, required no additional heating last winter. To build in Barcelona’s L’Ametlla del Vallès, the couple partnered with local architects @slowstudio.es, a firm renowned for designing and constructing houses with reduced energy consumption. "We decided to allocate a main part of the budget to the passive functioning of the house, investing in materials that would provide us with environmental quality and energy efficiency," says Jade Serra (@jade_slowstudio), partner and cofounder of the firm. “In this case, we worked with a thermal buffer: the patio greenhouse.” Separating the bedrooms from the common spaces, a glass-covered courtyard runs through the center of the home and creates a greenhouse effect, mediating the 1,340-square-foot home’s climate. “The result is an economical, natural system that is as—or more—efficient than controlled mechanical ventilation." Take the full tour of Carlo and Martí’s home at the link in bio.
–
Photos by @salvalopez
Story by @sallielewis.co

node.text:
This Costa Rican home, sitting on a forested, remote plot two hours from San José, was designed with spiritual transcendence in mind—along with off-grid sustainability. When architect María de la Paz Alice of @mazpazz_arquitectura first saw the site in the mountains of Palmichal de Acosta, she was skeptical due to its inaccessibility. Luckily for the client—a film producer and ocean conservationist who dreamed of a place where she could disconnect—Alice was game to take on the project. The home is called Casa Salvaje, or Wild House, an entirely autonomous and self-sustaining stone-and-concrete home that uses geometric openings to frame its tranquil surroundings. Teaming up with interior designer Ileana Guerrero—who worked with local artisans to craft custom furnishings for the living spaces—and landscape designer Jorge Salgado, the project is a breathtaking example of architecture that connects to the earth. The home’s entrance, which the architect refers to as “the vortex,” takes the form of a concrete cube with two prominent circular openings. Crystals encrusted in the floor capture and reflect the light that passes through the overhead oculus from the sun and moon. “As you walk in, the circular window framing the mountain view is the focal point, and the sky window above immediately connects you to your surroundings,” says the architect. "In every project, I try to provide at least one space that promotes a transcendental experience. I strive to create spaces that will benefit and expand people emotionally and spiritually, just as much as they do aesthetically." Take a walk through the inspiring escape at the link in bio.
–
Photos by @garcialachner
Story by @desert.ren
Window Installation by @grupovental

node.text:
After 14 years in a cramped, dimly lit apartment, a couple felt the need to head somewhere new. Once Irene Glezos and Julie Chartoff started searching for a new home, however, they quickly found that nothing in the market was a match for the period details and important memories of their current space: It was the home where they’d raised their first child, Max, who had passed. Instead of forcing the change of scenery, the couple turned to local architecture firm @worrellyeung to transform their 1,600-square-foot loft into an open, light-filled home with an additional bedroom and bathroom. Worrel Yeung’s co-founders, Max Worrell (@worrellmax) and Jejon Yeung (@mjejon), made the first move of taking out existing walls to open the space while allowing the visibility of historic windows, original plaster molding, and an industrial steel structure. The intervention, along with use of various structural elements, allowed the apartment to be organized as one large space that strikes the perfect balance between gathering areas and partitioned rooms. In addition to meeting the family’s needs, the renovation created a home that feels distinctly personal. A quiet material palette of ash wood elements, bone-white floors, monolithic gray pieces, and calming marble and stone elevates Irene and Julie's vast assortment of art, objects, and books. "The clients had some unique and fun requests such as crawling-height sleeping lofts, bookcase stairs, sprinkler pipes painted pink, a blue sink. But we listened," Yeung says. "It was a journey and mutual goal to see how playful we could be while keeping it sophisticated and timeless." Head to the link in bio to take the full tour of the Broadway Loft.
–
Photos by @atanz

node.text:
When this space-age prefab was discovered in South Africa, it had smashed windows and was without a front door. “Workers were knocking down a building nearby and we thought they were going to tear it down too,” says artist @craigbarnes_, who has since repaired the supernatural specimen. “It was a wreck. We found out who owned it, and on an impulse while on top of Table Mountain, we agreed to buy it.” The home’s history is just as exciting as Craig’s discovery. In 1965, Finnish designer Matti Suuronen set out to create an après-ski cabin that would be efficient to heat and easy to transport, giving rise to the Futuro home—truly a product of the Space Age with its sleek, UFO-like shape. Though it was marketed as a prefabricated tiny home suitable for the masses, fewer than 100 Futuro pods were made, with an estimated 60 still in existence. After a long process of coordinating logistics and timing, this Futuro house touched down in Somerset’s Marston Park in England, now offering guests a unique chance to savor an unusual slice of architectural history. To take the full tour of the Futuro House, head to the link in bio.
–
Photos by @chriswakefield.photography 
Restoration by @craigbarnes_

node.text:
While designing a home on a secluded plateau in Valle de Bravo, architect Fernanda Canales (@fernandacanales_arquitectura) knew the isolated location and temperamental weather would be a challenge: not only would the house need to be resilient enough to withstand weather whiplash, but it also had to create all of its own energy. Instead of pulling away from the challenges, Fernanda leaned into them, crafting a self-sufficient home around four courtyards that embrace the surroundings through landscape views and varying solar exposure. Within the courtyards, native landscaping furthers this indoor/outdoor connection, in addition to a green roof overhead. “Since the house is only one level, it almost disappears into the landscape,” notes the architect, who says that’s one of her favorite aspects of the weekend home. Hit the link in bio to see the full tour of Casa Terreno.
–
Photos by @rafaelgamo
Structural Engineering by @gersonhuerta
